awd_titl_txt: Novel flow control strategies for heat transfer enhancement in a minimal array of impinging jets
awd_abstract_narration:
PI:  Naguib, Ahmed
Proposal Number: 1603720

The goal of the proposed research is to investigate the flow behavior of arrays of jets used in several engineering applications - most prominent of which is turbine blade cooling in gas turbine engines. In addition, cooling effects that the flow from the jets generates when it impinges on a surface will be studied. 

The proposal is motivated by the significance of impinging jets for heating, cooling and drying in many industrial processes and engineering devices. A particularly significant application is turbine blade cooling in gas turbine engines, where effective cooling can have a strong favorable impact on engine efficiency, causing substantial reduction in fuel consumption and pollution. The goal of the proposed work is to study the potential for significant augmentation of heat transfer in impinging jet arrays using active flow control strategies. The control strategies, which are conceived based on detailed understanding of the spatio-temporal relationship between the jet's vortical structures and the surface heat flux, will be implemented using plasma actuators mounted around the lips of axisymmetric jets arranged in an inline array. The array size is kept to a minimum of three to enable reproduction of fundamental jet-jet interaction phenomena while avoiding the complexity of large-size arrays. The study will employ time-resolved flow visualization and phase-locked PIV measurements to capture flow-field information simultaneously with measurements of the average convection heat transfer coefficient using temperature-sensitive paint, and spatio-temporal wall heat flux information using thin-film gage arrays. Data will be acquired for a range of parameters including jet-to-impingement-wall spacing, jet-to-jet spacing, Reynolds number, control strategies/parameters, and crossflow presence. This work will result in the education of a graduate student and the involvement of undergraduate students in research, who will also be actively involved in the dissemination of the research to summer high-school students. The graduate and undergraduate researchers will be recruited from underrepresented groups with the aid of existing programs at Michigan State University. New course content will be developed on experimental fluid dynamics that will integrate results from this research.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Motivated by improving the efficiency of energy conversion devices, such as gas turbines, and other cooling/heating processes, this study was undertaken to investigate novel methods for controlling impinging jets. Such jets are found in practice in applications requiring large rates of cooling or heating. The main objectives were to study the effect of multi-modal excitation of a single as well as multiple jets on the vortex development in the jet and associated cooling of the impingement surface. Two excitation (forcing) schemes were to be considered: one that combines temporal modes, and the other spatial ones. Due to some challanges in the forcing  scheme, the work focused on the temporal scheme and a single impinging jet. The results demonstrated the ability to fundamentally change the jet vortex structure via features in bi-modal forcing that is not possible with the more commonly used pure-harmonic forcing. To understand how different vortex configurations might influence the heat transfer from the wall, complementary computer calculations were conducted to investigate the detailed physics of the heat transfer due to vortex-wall interaction. These results provided a novel insight showing that improvement in the heat transfer is possible if the jet vortex structure is manipulated such that two vortices merge together while interacting with the impingement wall. However, these results were obtained when isolated vortices interact with the wall. In the jet experiments, changes to the wall cooling in response to significant change in the jet vortex structure were found to be modest. This is attributed to the dominant influence of the jet mean flow on wall cooling. It is envisioned, however, that the manipulation of the jet by the bi-modal scheme investigated here might be significantly more effective at low jet velocities and for vortex-driven jets (such as synthetic jets).

Results from this work were presented at a number of conferences and published in conference and journal papers. Two PhD students carried out  the research work and an undergraduate student contributed to the efforts. The project contributed to the development of human resources as well as the establishment of a unique experimental facility that will enhance the research and education of future engineers.


Last Modified: 12/31/2021
Modified by: Ahmed Naguib

Image
  • Impinging jet imaging at the rate of 10,000 frames/s under bi-modal control. Time progresses from left to right with every 8th image shown. Seen is the progression of a vortex pairing event, which is accelerated appreciably relative to the unforced, or traditionally-forced jet.
    Basil Abdelmegied and Ahmed Naguib
    Copyrighted
    Ahmed Naguib
    Forced Impinging Jet Flow Visualization
